review.title: Parsing of Myanmar sentences with function tagging
review.abstract: This paper describes the use of Naive Bayes to address the task of assigning function tags and context free grammar (CFG) to parse Myanmar sentences. Part of the challenge of statistical function tagging for Myanmar sentences comes from the fact that Myanmar has free-phrase-order and a complex morphological system. Function tagging is a pre-processing step for parsing. In the task of function tagging, we use the functional annotated corpus and tag Myanmar sentences with correct segmentation, POS (part-of-speech) tagging and chunking information. We propose Myanmar grammar rules and apply context free grammar (CFG) to find out the parse tree of function tagged Myanmar sentences. Experiments show that our analysis achieves a good result with parsing of simple sentences and three types of complex sentences.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: We have taken Myanmar language for information processing. Myanmar is an agglutinative language with a very productive flexible system. This means that for any NLP application in Myanmar to be successful, some level of functional analysis is required. Without it, the development of grammatical relationships would not be feasible due to the sparse data problem that will inevitably exist in the training data. Our approach is part of the Myanmar to English machine translation project. If a high quality translation is to be achieved, language understanding is a necessity. One problem in Myanmar language processing is the lack of grammatical regularity in the language. This leads to very complex Myanmar grammar, in order to achieve satisfactory results, which in terms increases the complexity in the parsing process, it is desirable that simple grammar be used. Our proposed method uses two components. They are function tagging and parsing.

sections.heading: 3. MYANMAR LANGUAGE
sections.text: Myanmar (formerly Burma) is one of the Southeast Asian countries. Myanmar is home to 135 ethnic groups that speak more than one language and use different scripts to represent their respective languages. In total, the people of Myanmar speak 109 languages [11]. Myanmar's language is the official language and is more than a thousand years old.

sections.heading: 3.1. Features of Myanmar Language
sections.text: In general, the sentence in Myanmar follows the subject, object and verb pattern. However, the exchange of subject and object is acceptable. In contrast to the English language, Myanmar is a syntax of a relatively free phrase order language. Myanmar phrases can be written in any order as long as the verb phrase is at the end of the sentence. This can easily be illustrated by the example of "The verb lays the book on the table," as in Table 1. All are valid sentences [12]. In all cases, the subject is one (He), the object one (the book), the place one (on the table) and the verb one (the places). It is clear from the above example that the phrase sequence does not determine the functional structure in Myanmar and allows for tingling.

sections.text: It is well known that many postal positions can be used in a sentence from Myanmar. If the words in a sentence can be misplaced, the sentence can be abnormal. There are two types of sentences as a sentence construction: simple sentences (SS) and complex sentences (CS). In the simple sentence, additional sentences such as object, time and place can be added between subject and verb. In a complex sentence, there are two types of clauses called Independent clause (IC) and Dependent clause (DC). In a sentence, there must be at least one independent clause, but there may be more than one dependent clause in it. IC contains the last particle (sfp) at the end of a sentence [15]. sections.heading: 6. FUNCTION TAGSET
sections.text: Function tagging is a process of assigning syntactic categories such as subject, object, time and place to each word in the text document. These are conceptually responsive by encoding an event in the format "who has what with whom, where, when," which provides useful semantic information about the sentences. We use the function tags proposed in [16] because they are easier to maintain and can add new language functions.

sections.heading: 9.1. Context Free Grammar for Myanmar Sentences
sections.text: LANGUAGE, defined by a CFG (context-free grammar), is the set of strings that can be derived from the initial symbol S (for sentence). Core of a CFG grammar is a set of production rules that replaces individual variables with strings of variables and symbols. Grammar generates all strings that, starting with a special initial variable, can be achieved by applying the production rules until no more variables are left. sections.heading: 10. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
sections.text: In our corpus, all sentences can be classified further than two sentences; one is a simple sentence where each sentence has no more than 15 words; the other is a complex sentence where each sentence has more than 15 words; there are 1600 simple sentences and 2,300 complex sentences in the corpus; for evaluation purposes, various sentences from Myanmar middle school textbooks and Myanmar history books are used as a test sentence; there are about 2,200 sentences in the test sentence; after applying the system based on grammar, it has been shown that the system can easily generate the parse tree for a sentence if the sentence structure complies with grammar rules; our program only tests the sentence structure according to grammar rules; so if the sentence structure complies with the grammar rule, the program recognizes the sentence as the correct sentence and generates a parse tree; otherwise, it will indicate the output as an error; Table 10 shows the total performance for the proposed system; the proposed system yields 96.68% of precision, 93.05% of memory, and 4.83% of the different sets of yardsticks.

sections.heading: 11. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: We use context-free grammar for parsing because it is easier to maintain and can add new language characteristics; the parse tree can be built by using functional characteristics; because functional characteristics are a pre-processing step for parsing, the errors that occur in abandoning the functional characteristics affect the parse tree; the corpus can be balanced because the probability of the naive Bayesian framework simply describes uncertainty; creating the corpus is time-consuming; the corpus is the resource for Myanmar's development into the English translation system; and we expect the corpus to be continuously expanded in the future because the sentence tested can be inserted into the corpus; in this work, we have looked at a limited number of sentences from Myanmar to construct the grammar rules; in future work, we need to consider as many sentences as possible, and some more tags for constructing the grammar rules because Myanmar is a language that is freely ordered by phrases.
